Hi all,

I'd like to learn about how REST principles have been and can be a=
pplied
to certain kinds of user interface cruft. I've just joined a company=

that consciously applies REST to a back-end server interface, but the
fron=
t-end user interface is not very RESTy at all. I'm struggling to
imagine ho=
w certain features of that user interface, in common with user
interfaces I=
've seen in several Web applications, could be redesigned
consistent with R=
EST principles.

These are some of the features I'm wondering about:

1. Lo=
gin Page

The support for HTTP Basic authentication in common Web browsers =
is not
particularly user friendly. Therefore, Web applications that require=

user authentication universally present an HTML login page with a form
tha=
t, when submitted, results in a cookie being set in the browser. This
cooki=
e is often a session key, which is obviously not RESTful; on the
other hand=
, if the cookie were used purely as an authentication token
not requiring s=
erver state, would such use be consistent with REST?

2. Current User

Once=
 the user is logged in, it is common to have at the very least the
user's n=
ame displayed in the corner of every page of the application. At
a further =
extreme, any given page may be completely different per user,
such as a use=
r-customizable "dashboard". As I understand REST, the
representation return=
ed from a GET should not depend on the
authorization state, but only on the=
 URI.

What if instead of </dashboard> the URI was </joe/dashboard>? Any us=
er
other than joe who tried to GET that resource could simply be forbidden.=

But does that make sense for putting the user's name at the top of every
p=
age of the application? Should every page view that a user can see be
consi=
dered a resource specific to that user?

3. Menus, Etc.

I wrote some comme=
nts and questions on this topic at the bottom of
<http://conveyor.com/RESTw=
iki/moin.cgi/HowWikiComparesToRest>. In that
discussion, it had been posite=
d that a RESTful Wiki would use PUT for
editing pages. However, every page =
of a typical Wiki has a menu bar at
the top & other bits of information lik=
e the last modified date at the
bottom, none of which can be edited by user=
s.

More generally, Web applications tend to have lots of menus on the top
=
and left of every page that aren't directly relevant to the content of
the =
page, but are really window dressing for the entire site. How can
all that =
UI cruft be understood in a RESTful way?

Justin Sampson
